paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Two novel mutations in the KCNH2 gene were identified, associated with Long QT Syndrome in two patients.

patients.phenotype: Long QT Syndrome, episodes of Torsade de Pointes

individual_records.phenotype_details: Prolonged QT interval (QTc = 510 ms), runs of TdP
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The first index patient who carried the P632L mutation was a male newborn that exhibited runs of TdP and LQTS.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Prolonged QT interval (QTc = 542 ms), multiple episodes of TdP
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The second index patient (S428P) was a 14-year-old girl when reported had a QTc = 542 ms.

functional_data.summary: Both mutations (P632L and S428P) resulted in no measurable hERG current in HEK cells.

variants.segregation_data: Both mutations were found in affected individuals.
variants.evidence_level: strong evidence based on functional assays and clinical presentation
variants.additional_notes: The mutations were characterized through in vitro studies and associated with severe clinical phenotypes.
key_quotes: The infant also showed right atrial enlargement and right ventricular hypertrophy.
Pacemaker and beta-blockers were the therapeutic interventions used for the patient.
